Smurfit rejects in quite aggressive terms. Opportunistic and conditional, fails to reflect the intrinsic value of the business and its short, medium, and long-term prospects. That kind of thing.

Saying there's not a lot of antitrust worry, but not a lot in the way of synergies either.

BE11:40am

So, don't go crazy on price.

BE11:40am

Both businesses are integrated paper and packaging companies, although International Paper has a wider paper business whereas Smurfit is more focused on the packaging segment. International Paper has c75% of sales in the Americas, with most of the other 25% in Europe/Russia. Smurfit is the reverse with c25% in the US. Although we would note that IP only makes 8% of EBITDA in EMEA/Russia. Both companies are the leaders in their respective "home" markets in Kraftliner production. We would see only limited potential issues with the competition authorities on any combination given Smurfit's share of US containerboard production is very small and vice-versa IP in Europe.

Forester I had a look at the locations - seems quite a good fit!
11:41 am
BE11:41am

We see somewhat limited synergy benefits between Europe and America based operations, but there would be synergies in the overlapping exposures within regions and as the packaging sector becomes more global it would create a world leader. In terms of valuation, recent transactions in the European sector have been transacted at multiples ranging from c13-18x EBIT, (or 10-15x EBITDA) pre synergies falling significantly post synergies which are often targeted at up to c4% of sales (with a low of 2%) – post synergy multiples have fallen to more like 8-13x EBIT. However, we would note that: (1) these have generally been smaller transactions for private companies; and (2) it is questionable if this level of synergies would be available in a trans-Atlantic deal of this nature. As an example of the range of potential valuation scenarios, if a post synergy EBIT multiple of 10x was used (broadly at the mid point of past transactions), this would equate to an EV range of c€11-14bn based on 2-4% synergies, which translates into an equity range of more like €9-11bn. We base our Smurfit price target of €30 on 7.7x 17E EV/EBITDA.

Soundbuy @Forester - exactly.........

BE11:45am

The main question circulating today is why Smurfit has chosen to pre-announce this transaction. International Paper has made no secret of its desire to acquire in Europe. But there is no love lost between these two companies. It would not be a normal line of defence to announce that you have been approached. However, with potentially the threat of IP making the first public statement, and perhaps a confidence in the value defence they have hear, it may be that Smurfit is seeking to steal the initiative here. Historical transactions point to a wide range of multiples, but Smurfit’s market position, strong ROCE and positive growth outlook coupled with the strong strategic merit to this transaction for IP would point to a value at the top end of this range. An offer at €38 per share is 8.7x 2018 EBITDA. Recent multiples would justify a price north of €40, synergies permitting. The questions will be how close to the upper end of the historic multiple range IP is prepared to go and whether Smurfit has the support of the register such that it can push a meaningful bid/ask spread here.

December69 - Sceptic @VV75 should be interesting to see how it unfolds.

Based on Fy19 forecasts a 9x EV/EBITDA on SKG would imply a 3670c equity valuation (28% premium to last night), 10x implies 4260c (49% premium) and 11x implies 4850c (69% premium). At the time of the last speculation a leaked report suggested advisors to IP were valuing Smurfit Kappa on €36/share. Based on International Paper's balance sheet we estimate that increasing gearing to 5x would underpin an all cash offer. Given the stage we are in the cycle that would prove a risk in our view.

Mouselet Good morning miscellaneous people
BE11:49am

International Paper have stated they wanted to grow containerboard business which has little scope in the US and have recently withdrawn from Asia. Having already committed some capital to a mill project in Madrid the intention is already clear on Europe. Buying the number one player would clearly be attractive. There is a complimentary footprint in South America where IP’s only material presence is in Brazil. SKG is number one corrugator in South America. With regard to the US market packaging is pretty unsophisticated. SKG’s leadership on this front would help drive this part of the US business on.

BE11:56am

Here's RBC to summarise.

BE11:56am

FY17 revenues beat by 4%. Regionally, UK sales growth of +28% came in broadly in-line with our forecast. On a CCY basis, Established Markets sales growth of +84% yoy came in above our forecast of +58% due to higher revenue contribution from recently acquired SkipTheDishes. Developing Markets sales growth also came in above our estimate at +59% (RBC +53%) while Australia & New Zealand sales growth came in slightly softer at +25% (RBC +28%).
FY17 underlying EBITDA ahead by 2%, driven by Australia/NZ while UK misses estimates. Group underlying EBITDA margin of 30.0% was below our estimate of 30.8% (consensus 30.7%) mainly due to lower profitability in the UK market, reporting an underlying EBITDA margin of 51.2% (consensus 52.7%) as Just Eat invests in delivery-related services (1.6% of UK revenue). Australia & New Zealand underlying EBITDA was ahead of expectations due to disciplined cost management, while other regions were broadly in line. The Group is making a significant non-cash impairment of £180m related to the 2015 acquisition of Menulog. Otherwise, adjusted basic EPS is in line with consensus.
FY18 underlying EBITDA guidance implies 19-27% downgrade to consensus. For FY18, management has guided for revenues of £660-700mn, the mid-point of which is 1% ahead of consensus and underlying EBITDA of £165-185mn vs. consensus at £227m. As management cites intensifying competition in certain markets, the Group will increase investments in delivery services namely in the UK, Canada, Australia & New Zealand and Developing Markets.

11:56 am
BE11:57am

Just Eat is attractively positioned, in our view, enjoying a leading position in all of its markets and should sustain high levels of growth. We see potential upside
to revenue expectations, although believe investments in own delivery to weigh on share price performance near-term.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

While increased investment from the new CEO was expected by all, the magnitude of the number for 2018 may come as a negative surprise, unless Mr Plumb can do a good job in explaining why the £50m should be spent on delivery and why this will result in material incremental value creation over the medium term. Our initial thoughts are that we do not think the company should stand still and let competitors have a free ride at
the delivery market and that £50m for an option on delivery in three large markets does not sound like a huge bet. We do, however, expect most the questions to be asked today, but
most of the answers to come at the company’s capital markets day in June.

BE12:01pm

We are not surprised by the new CEO detailing incremental investment; typically this is what happens when a new strategic path is detailed. That said, neither we (nor consensus) had included this investment in our base-case assumptions as we had entered into a “wait and see” mode ahead of these results. Further investment in delivery was top of the likelihood list, but if we were honest we did not expect a figure for total investment for 2018 to the magnitude of £50m. 2017 numbers were solid and core business 2018 guidance is broadly in line. However, unless Mr Plumb can do a good job at the investor presentation in explaining what exactly these new investments will be spent on, and how this will increase medium-term consensus expectations – which may not be until the capital markets day in June – we expect shares could react negatively to this announcement, especially after the extremely strong recent share price performance.

BE12:01pm

And Barclays ......

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

The guidance implies 21-28% revenue growth and 1-13% for EBITDA. This is disappointing especially as the business benefits from the Hungry House integration and service charge next year, which we estimate add £28m and £15m in EBITDA respectively, meaning that the actual investments are over ~£90m. We are wondering if such an investment is really required?

Blank canvas thanks for everything today.
BE12:02pm

Just Eat is trading at 29x headline FY19E PE. We see this valuation as attractive considering its international peer group, the growth at offer and the net cash and value of the Brazil business (accounted as an associate). We are, therefore, Overweight with a price target of 1000p based on 30x FY19E PE (ex. Brazil and cash) or 34x our headline PE.

12:07 pm
BE12:07pm

FX is a problem, hurricanes are a positive, and against the two nothing much changes.

BE12:07pm

Here's Cazenove to summarise where we are.

BE12:08pm

Ashtead’s Q3 beats consensus at both revenue and adj. EBITDA. In terms of trading dynamics, the trends are largely expected with rental growth of +24% and similar growth rates in terms of earnings development. The operating leverage is lower than in our model despite a good yield number (rates ~+3% y/y, yield neutral) and is likely the result of higher cost inflation than we forecast but we would expect this to be addressed on the call. Capex is guided to the upper end of the range with initial capex guide for FY19 as flat on FY18, maintaining a high level but this is probably no better than expected and again is something for the call. In a separate release, the group has also announced CFO Suzanne Wood will stand down to be replaced by Michael Pratt who steps up from his role as Deputy Finance Director. Whilst the move is a surprise the reasoning – to spend more time in the US – makes sense and Mr Pratt’s experience within the group should stand him in good stead. The unchanged guidance for the full-year suggests unchanged consensus with underlying upgrades being absorbed by the increased FX headwind, our sense is that consensus likely does move up low single-digits, given the momentum in the business though clearly this will also depend on the FX rates consensus is struck at.

J Sainsbury PLC (SBRY:LSE): Last: 249.60, down 3.3 (-1.30%), High: 254.80, Low: 247.00, Volume: 4.99m
Market Analyst 12pm auction = for larger sized orders to limit impact, coinciding with vol low of day; also offers extra price for mid-session mark-to-market
BE12:16pm

HSBC's written off Nielsen, which shows similar trends. Here's the gist.

BE12:16pm

Tesco (sales +3.1%, market share 27.2%, down 20bps yoy. 2-year sales 3.9%). As discussed at our recent Future Consumer Forum, the Tesco recovery is sustained and real. Tesco is outgrowing the rest of the Big4 in percentage terms, but importantly it is growing considerably faster in cash terms. For example, we estimate it has outgrown Sainsbury by c7:1 over the last year in cash sales. There are signs that Tesco momentum grew across the 12 weeks, with Tesco winning more shoppers and increasing basket size. Tesco has momentum and with the Booker merger completing, this momentum looks set to accelerate.

Sainsbury's (sales +0.8%, market share 15.3%, down 50 bps. 2-year sales +0.5%). This is concerning and JS is losing momentum. A 50bps fall in market share vs last year suggests that share could dip below 15% if the trend is not reversed - and there is no indication this is happening. JS remains the weakest of the Big4. Stripping out two years of inflation leaves JS with meaningful volume losses on sales up just 0.5%.

Morrisons (sales +2.0, market share 9.9%, down 20bps. 2-year sales +3.9%). Against tough comps, Morrisons is underperforming over one year, but it matches Tesco for percentage growth on a 2-year basis (but obviously lags on a cash basis). Market share at Morrisons has dipped below 10% and there are signs that Morrisons is currently finding trading a lot tougher, in part due to ASDA recovery.

12:16 pm
WM Morrison Supermarkets PLC (MRW:LSE): Last: 227.90, up 2.4 (+1.06%), High: 229.60, Low: 225.80, Volume: 2.68m

12:17 pm
BE12:17pm

The Booker merger is now complete and the market can focus on the merits of the two businesses and the opportunities for collaboration. Sales – both Tesco and Booker have strong underlying momentum. Profitability – good progress is being made towards the margin target at ‘core’ Tesco and the Booker synergies look eminently achievable. Cash generation – Tesco is moving towards the cash-generation/return model that served Booker so well. We think the stock is very reasonably priced and, given we forecast 24% EPS growth in the coming year, Tesco only needs to hold its current P/E multiple to hit our price target (which implies 26% upside).

Based on current spot rates, we cut our 2018E PBT from £190m to £181m, 10% below consensus of £202m. Management anticipates 2018E tax rate of 31%, well ahead of our forecast of 26%. We cut our 2018E and 2019E EPS by 11% and 4% respectively.

12:33 pm
BE12:34pm

Power Solutions Utility — continues to struggle with order intake of 799MW, below our forecast of 826MW and short of required 1200MW. We cut our 2018E trading profit from £158m in 2016, £96m in 2017 to £55m in 2018E, due to lower contribution from Argentina (£5m less trading profit), termination of Japanese contract (£15m) and loss of Zimbabwe contract (£20m). During 2017 management increased bad debtor provision by USD23m to reflect collection challenges in Africa and Venezuela. Utility business has shrunk from two-thirds of group trading profit to just over 25% in last few years.
